Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Have you ever noticed how the full moon looks bigger when it's near the horizon than when it's high over head? If so, you're not alone. People have wondered about this strange effect since ancient times, and surprisingly, we still don't have a great explanation, but that's not for lack of trying. Some of the greatest minds in history - Aristotle, Ptolemy, Da Vinci, Decartes - have all wrestled with this problem and failed to generate an adequate explanation. One of the first ideas suggested was that the image of the moon in the sky really is bigger near the horizon. Perhaps the Earth's atmosphere acts like a giant lens, magnifying the moon as it rises and sets. But this explanation doesn't cut it. If anything, the refraction of the atmosphere would make the moon look slightly smaller. Plus, if you actually measure the size of the visible moon at different positions, it doesn't change at all. But then, why does it still seem bigger when it's rising? This must be some kind of optical illusion. The question is, which one? One explanation is the Ebbinghaus Illusion, where two identical objects look different because of the relative size of the objects they're surrounded by. Here the two center circles are actually the same size. Maybe the moon looks bigger near the horizon because it's next to tiny trees, houses, and towers in the distance. But when the moon is higher up, it's surrounded by the vast darkness of the night sky and looks tiny by comparison. Another possibility is the famous Ponzo Illusion. If you've ever tried to draw in perspective, you know that the closer something is to the horizon, the smaller you should draw it. Our brain compensates automatically for this by perceiving objects near the horizon as larger than they actually appear. The two yellow lines in this drawing are the same size, but the upper one seems bigger because we interpret it as receding farther into the horizon. So, between Ponzo and Ebbinghaus, it seems like we've solved the mystery of the moon illusion, but, unfortunately, there are a few details that complicate things. For one thing, if this was just the Ebbinghaus effect, then we would expect the moon illusion to disappear for pilots flying high above the clouds since there wouldn't be any other smaller objects near the horizon. But in fact, pilots and sailors out on the ocean still claim to see the moon illusion. On the other hand, if it's just our brain's autocorrecting the size of objects near the horizon, then we'd expect the moon illusion to be visible inside a planetarium, where the whole sky, including the horizon, is displayed on a spherical dome overhead. Studies have shown, though, that this is not the case. To make matters worse, it seems the moon illusion disappears entirely if you just bend over and look at the moon between your legs. Now, this is just getting ridiculous! One of the most promising explanations today is known as Convergence Micropsia. Our brains judge the distance to objects and their apparent size by the focus of our eyes. When looking at the horizon, your eyes focus far off into the distance so your brain knows you're looking far away. The moon appears a certain size. Your brain thinks it's far away, which it is, so you naturally conclude the moon must be big. But when looking up at the night sky, there's nothing for your eyes to focus on, so they default to their rest focus, which is a point just a few meters away. Now your brain thinks the moon is much closer than it really is, so you naturally conclude the moon's not as big as you thought it was. Rather than explain why the moon looks so big near the horizon, Convergence Microspia explains why the moon looks so small when overhead. Still not satisfied? Well, frankly, neither are many scientists, so the debate over the moon illusion still rages on and may continue as long as we still see it in the night sky.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is the moon illusion?
Options: A. The fact that the same side of the moon is always facing earth, B. The appearance of a “man in the moon”, C. The apparent change in size of the moon as it rises and sets, D. The disappearance of the moon during a lunar eclipse
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Which of the following historical figures attempted to explain the moon illusion? Options: A. Galileo, Newton, and Einstein, B. Aristotle, Ptolemy, Da Vinci, and Decartes, C. Kepler, Copernicus, and Tycho Brahe, D. Leonardo, Michelangelo, and Raphael Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was one of the initial explanations proposed for the moon illusion, and why was it rejected? Options: A. The Earth's atmosphere acts like a giant lens, but this would make the moon look larger., B. The Earth's atmosphere acts like a giant lens, but this would make the moon look slightly smaller., C. The moon is actually larger near the horizon due to its elliptical orbit., D. The moon appears larger due to the reflection of light from the Earth's surface. Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the Ebbinghaus Illusion, and how might it relate to the moon illusion? Options: A. The Ebbinghaus Illusion is an optical illusion where two identical objects appear different due to their relative motion., B. The Ebbinghaus Illusion is an optical illusion where two identical objects appear different due to the relative size of the objects they're surrounded by., C. The Ebbinghaus Illusion is an optical illusion where two identical objects appear different due to their relative color., D. The Ebbinghaus Illusion is an optical illusion where two identical objects appear different due to their relative distance. Correct Option: B
Question 4: According to the Ebbinghaus Illusion explanation, what would you expect to happen to the moon illusion if you were a pilot flying high above the clouds? Options: A. The moon illusion would become more pronounced., B. The moon illusion would remain the same., C. The moon illusion would disappear., D. The moon illusion would be reversed. Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the Ponzo Illusion, and how might it relate to the moon illusion? Options: A. The Ponzo Illusion is an optical illusion where two identical objects appear different due to their relative size., B. The Ponzo Illusion is an optical illusion where two identical objects appear different due to their perceived distance., C. The Ponzo Illusion is an optical illusion where two identical objects appear different due to their relative motion., D. The Ponzo Illusion is an optical illusion where two identical objects appear different due to their relative color. Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is Convergence Micropsia, and how does it attempt to explain the moon illusion? Options: A. Convergence Micropsia is a type of optical illusion that explains why the moon appears larger near the horizon., B. Convergence Micropsia is a type of optical illusion that explains why the moon appears smaller when overhead due to the way our brains judge distance and size., C. Convergence Micropsia is a type of optical illusion that explains why the moon appears larger near the horizon due to the way our brains process visual information., D. Convergence Micropsia is a type of optical illusion that explains why the moon appears smaller when overhead due to the way our brains compensate for the Earth's atmosphere. Correct Option: B
Question 7: According to the Convergence Micropsia explanation, what happens to our brain's perception of the moon's distance when we look up at the night sky? Options: A. Our brain perceives the moon as being farther away., B. Our brain perceives the moon as being closer due to the default rest focus of our eyes., C. Our brain perceives the moon as being at the same distance as when we look at the horizon., D. Our brain is unable to perceive the moon's distance. Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is a criticism of the Ebbinghaus Illusion explanation for the moon illusion? Options: A. The explanation is too simplistic., B. The explanation is not supported by empirical evidence., C. The explanation cannot account for the fact that pilots and sailors still claim to see the moon illusion even when there are no smaller objects near the horizon., D. The explanation is not a valid optical illusion. Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the current state of the debate over the moon illusion? Options: A. The debate has been resolved, and the Convergence Micropsia explanation is widely accepted., B. The debate is ongoing, and scientists continue to propose new explanations and test existing ones., C. The debate has been abandoned, and scientists have moved on to more pressing topics., D. The debate is stuck, and no progress has been made in recent years. Correct Option: B
Question 10: What happens to the moon illusion when you bend over and look at the moon between your legs? Options: A. The moon illusion becomes more pronounced., B. The moon illusion remains the same., C. The moon illusion disappears entirely., D. The moon illusion is reversed. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Have you ever noticed how the full moon looks bigger when it's near the horizon than when it's high over head? If so, you're not alone. People have wondered about this strange effect since ancient times, and surprisingly, we still don't have a great explanation, but that's not for lack of trying. Some of the greatest minds in history - Aristotle, Ptolemy, Da Vinci, Decartes - have all wrestled with this problem and failed to generate an adequate explanation. One of the first ideas suggested was that the image of the moon in the sky really is bigger near the horizon. Perhaps the Earth's atmosphere acts like a giant lens, magnifying the moon as it rises and sets. But this explanation doesn't cut it. If anything, the refraction of the atmosphere would make the moon look slightly smaller. Plus, if you actually measure the size of the visible moon at different positions, it doesn't change at all. But then, why does it still seem bigger when it's rising? This must be some kind of optical illusion. The question is, which one? One explanation is the Ebbinghaus Illusion, where two identical objects look different because of the relative size of the objects they're surrounded by. Here the two center circles are actually the same size. Maybe the moon looks bigger near the horizon because it's next to tiny trees, houses, and towers in the distance. But when the moon is higher up, it's surrounded by the vast darkness of the night sky and looks tiny by comparison. Another possibility is the famous Ponzo Illusion. If you've ever tried to draw in perspective, you know that the closer something is to the horizon, the smaller you should draw it. Our brain compensates automatically for this by perceiving objects near the horizon as larger than they actually appear. The two yellow lines in this drawing are the same size, but the upper one seems bigger because we interpret it as receding farther into the horizon. So, between Ponzo and Ebbinghaus, it seems like we've solved the mystery of the moon illusion, but, unfortunately, there are a few details that complicate things. For one thing, if this was just the Ebbinghaus effect, then we would expect the moon illusion to disappear for pilots flying high above the clouds since there wouldn't be any other smaller objects near the horizon. But in fact, pilots and sailors out on the ocean still claim to see the moon illusion. On the other hand, if it's just our brain's autocorrecting the size of objects near the horizon, then we'd expect the moon illusion to be visible inside a planetarium, where the whole sky, including the horizon, is displayed on a spherical dome overhead. Studies have shown, though, that this is not the case. To make matters worse, it seems the moon illusion disappears entirely if you just bend over and look at the moon between your legs. Now, this is just getting ridiculous! One of the most promising explanations today is known as Convergence Micropsia. Our brains judge the distance to objects and their apparent size by the focus of our eyes. When looking at the horizon, your eyes focus far off into the distance so your brain knows you're looking far away. The moon appears a certain size. Your brain thinks it's far away, which it is, so you naturally conclude the moon must be big. But when looking up at the night sky, there's nothing for your eyes to focus on, so they default to their rest focus, which is a point just a few meters away. Now your brain thinks the moon is much closer than it really is, so you naturally conclude the moon's not as big as you thought it was. Rather than explain why the moon looks so big near the horizon, Convergence Microspia explains why the moon looks so small when overhead. Still not satisfied? Well, frankly, neither are many scientists, so the debate over the moon illusion still rages on and may continue as long as we still see it in the night sky.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What effect could the atmosphere have in contributing to the moon illusion?
Options: A. The atmosphere would make the moon appear smaller at sunrise or sunset., B. The atmosphere would make the moon disappear at sunrise or sunset., C. The atmosphere changes the apparent color of the moon., D. The atmosphere makes it look like the same side of the moon always faces us.
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Have you ever noticed how the full moon looks bigger when it's near the horizon than when it's high over head? If so, you're not alone. People have wondered about this strange effect since ancient times, and surprisingly, we still don't have a great explanation, but that's not for lack of trying. Some of the greatest minds in history - Aristotle, Ptolemy, Da Vinci, Decartes - have all wrestled with this problem and failed to generate an adequate explanation. One of the first ideas suggested was that the image of the moon in the sky really is bigger near the horizon. Perhaps the Earth's atmosphere acts like a giant lens, magnifying the moon as it rises and sets. But this explanation doesn't cut it. If anything, the refraction of the atmosphere would make the moon look slightly smaller. Plus, if you actually measure the size of the visible moon at different positions, it doesn't change at all. But then, why does it still seem bigger when it's rising? This must be some kind of optical illusion. The question is, which one? One explanation is the Ebbinghaus Illusion, where two identical objects look different because of the relative size of the objects they're surrounded by. Here the two center circles are actually the same size. Maybe the moon looks bigger near the horizon because it's next to tiny trees, houses, and towers in the distance. But when the moon is higher up, it's surrounded by the vast darkness of the night sky and looks tiny by comparison. Another possibility is the famous Ponzo Illusion. If you've ever tried to draw in perspective, you know that the closer something is to the horizon, the smaller you should draw it. Our brain compensates automatically for this by perceiving objects near the horizon as larger than they actually appear. The two yellow lines in this drawing are the same size, but the upper one seems bigger because we interpret it as receding farther into the horizon. So, between Ponzo and Ebbinghaus, it seems like we've solved the mystery of the moon illusion, but, unfortunately, there are a few details that complicate things. For one thing, if this was just the Ebbinghaus effect, then we would expect the moon illusion to disappear for pilots flying high above the clouds since there wouldn't be any other smaller objects near the horizon. But in fact, pilots and sailors out on the ocean still claim to see the moon illusion. On the other hand, if it's just our brain's autocorrecting the size of objects near the horizon, then we'd expect the moon illusion to be visible inside a planetarium, where the whole sky, including the horizon, is displayed on a spherical dome overhead. Studies have shown, though, that this is not the case. To make matters worse, it seems the moon illusion disappears entirely if you just bend over and look at the moon between your legs. Now, this is just getting ridiculous! One of the most promising explanations today is known as Convergence Micropsia. Our brains judge the distance to objects and their apparent size by the focus of our eyes. When looking at the horizon, your eyes focus far off into the distance so your brain knows you're looking far away. The moon appears a certain size. Your brain thinks it's far away, which it is, so you naturally conclude the moon must be big. But when looking up at the night sky, there's nothing for your eyes to focus on, so they default to their rest focus, which is a point just a few meters away. Now your brain thinks the moon is much closer than it really is, so you naturally conclude the moon's not as big as you thought it was. Rather than explain why the moon looks so big near the horizon, Convergence Microspia explains why the moon looks so small when overhead. Still not satisfied? Well, frankly, neither are many scientists, so the debate over the moon illusion still rages on and may continue as long as we still see it in the night sky.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which sentence best describes the Ebbinghaus illusion?
Options: A. Two identical circles appear different because of the relative size of objects around them., B. Our brains overestimate the size of objects located closer to the horizon., C. Pilots in airplanes have nothing to compare the moon’s size to, so it looks smaller., D. The focus of our eyes impacts how large we perceive an object to be.
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Have you ever noticed how the full moon looks bigger when it's near the horizon than when it's high over head? If so, you're not alone. People have wondered about this strange effect since ancient times, and surprisingly, we still don't have a great explanation, but that's not for lack of trying. Some of the greatest minds in history - Aristotle, Ptolemy, Da Vinci, Decartes - have all wrestled with this problem and failed to generate an adequate explanation. One of the first ideas suggested was that the image of the moon in the sky really is bigger near the horizon. Perhaps the Earth's atmosphere acts like a giant lens, magnifying the moon as it rises and sets. But this explanation doesn't cut it. If anything, the refraction of the atmosphere would make the moon look slightly smaller. Plus, if you actually measure the size of the visible moon at different positions, it doesn't change at all. But then, why does it still seem bigger when it's rising? This must be some kind of optical illusion. The question is, which one? One explanation is the Ebbinghaus Illusion, where two identical objects look different because of the relative size of the objects they're surrounded by. Here the two center circles are actually the same size. Maybe the moon looks bigger near the horizon because it's next to tiny trees, houses, and towers in the distance. But when the moon is higher up, it's surrounded by the vast darkness of the night sky and looks tiny by comparison. Another possibility is the famous Ponzo Illusion. If you've ever tried to draw in perspective, you know that the closer something is to the horizon, the smaller you should draw it. Our brain compensates automatically for this by perceiving objects near the horizon as larger than they actually appear. The two yellow lines in this drawing are the same size, but the upper one seems bigger because we interpret it as receding farther into the horizon. So, between Ponzo and Ebbinghaus, it seems like we've solved the mystery of the moon illusion, but, unfortunately, there are a few details that complicate things. For one thing, if this was just the Ebbinghaus effect, then we would expect the moon illusion to disappear for pilots flying high above the clouds since there wouldn't be any other smaller objects near the horizon. But in fact, pilots and sailors out on the ocean still claim to see the moon illusion. On the other hand, if it's just our brain's autocorrecting the size of objects near the horizon, then we'd expect the moon illusion to be visible inside a planetarium, where the whole sky, including the horizon, is displayed on a spherical dome overhead. Studies have shown, though, that this is not the case. To make matters worse, it seems the moon illusion disappears entirely if you just bend over and look at the moon between your legs. Now, this is just getting ridiculous! One of the most promising explanations today is known as Convergence Micropsia. Our brains judge the distance to objects and their apparent size by the focus of our eyes. When looking at the horizon, your eyes focus far off into the distance so your brain knows you're looking far away. The moon appears a certain size. Your brain thinks it's far away, which it is, so you naturally conclude the moon must be big. But when looking up at the night sky, there's nothing for your eyes to focus on, so they default to their rest focus, which is a point just a few meters away. Now your brain thinks the moon is much closer than it really is, so you naturally conclude the moon's not as big as you thought it was. Rather than explain why the moon looks so big near the horizon, Convergence Microspia explains why the moon looks so small when overhead. Still not satisfied? Well, frankly, neither are many scientists, so the debate over the moon illusion still rages on and may continue as long as we still see it in the night sky.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which sentence best describes the Ponzo illusion?
Options: A. Two identical circles appear different because of the relative size of objects around them., B. Our brains overestimate the size of objects located closer to the horizon., C. Pilots in airplanes have nothing to compare the moon’s size to, so it looks smaller., D. The focus of our eyes impacts how large we perceive an object to be.
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Which of the following historical figures attempted to explain the moon illusion? Options: A. Galileo, Newton, and Einstein, B. Aristotle, Ptolemy, Da Vinci, and Decartes, C. Kepler, Copernicus, and Tycho Brahe, D. Leonardo, Michelangelo, and Raphael Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was one of the initial explanations proposed for the moon illusion, and why was it rejected? Options: A. The Earth's atmosphere acts like a giant lens, but this would make the moon look larger., B. The Earth's atmosphere acts like a giant lens, but this would make the moon look slightly smaller., C. The moon is actually larger near the horizon due to its elliptical orbit., D. The moon appears larger due to the reflection of light from the Earth's surface. Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the Ebbinghaus Illusion, and how might it relate to the moon illusion? Options: A. The Ebbinghaus Illusion is an optical illusion where two identical objects appear different due to their relative motion., B. The Ebbinghaus Illusion is an optical illusion where two identical objects appear different due to the relative size of the objects they're surrounded by., C. The Ebbinghaus Illusion is an optical illusion where two identical objects appear different due to their relative color., D. The Ebbinghaus Illusion is an optical illusion where two identical objects appear different due to their relative distance. Correct Option: B
Question 4: According to the Ebbinghaus Illusion explanation, what would you expect to happen to the moon illusion if you were a pilot flying high above the clouds? Options: A. The moon illusion would become more pronounced., B. The moon illusion would remain the same., C. The moon illusion would disappear., D. The moon illusion would be reversed. Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the Ponzo Illusion, and how might it relate to the moon illusion? Options: A. The Ponzo Illusion is an optical illusion where two identical objects appear different due to their relative size., B. The Ponzo Illusion is an optical illusion where two identical objects appear different due to their perceived distance., C. The Ponzo Illusion is an optical illusion where two identical objects appear different due to their relative motion., D. The Ponzo Illusion is an optical illusion where two identical objects appear different due to their relative color. Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is Convergence Micropsia, and how does it attempt to explain the moon illusion? Options: A. Convergence Micropsia is a type of optical illusion that explains why the moon appears larger near the horizon., B. Convergence Micropsia is a type of optical illusion that explains why the moon appears smaller when overhead due to the way our brains judge distance and size., C. Convergence Micropsia is a type of optical illusion that explains why the moon appears larger near the horizon due to the way our brains process visual information., D. Convergence Micropsia is a type of optical illusion that explains why the moon appears smaller when overhead due to the way our brains compensate for the Earth's atmosphere. Correct Option: B
Question 7: According to the Convergence Micropsia explanation, what happens to our brain's perception of the moon's distance when we look up at the night sky? Options: A. Our brain perceives the moon as being farther away., B. Our brain perceives the moon as being closer due to the default rest focus of our eyes., C. Our brain perceives the moon as being at the same distance as when we look at the horizon., D. Our brain is unable to perceive the moon's distance. Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is a criticism of the Ebbinghaus Illusion explanation for the moon illusion? Options: A. The explanation is too simplistic., B. The explanation is not supported by empirical evidence., C. The explanation cannot account for the fact that pilots and sailors still claim to see the moon illusion even when there are no smaller objects near the horizon., D. The explanation is not a valid optical illusion. Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the current state of the debate over the moon illusion? Options: A. The debate has been resolved, and the Convergence Micropsia explanation is widely accepted., B. The debate is ongoing, and scientists continue to propose new explanations and test existing ones., C. The debate has been abandoned, and scientists have moved on to more pressing topics., D. The debate is stuck, and no progress has been made in recent years. Correct Option: B
Question 10: What happens to the moon illusion when you bend over and look at the moon between your legs? Options: A. The moon illusion becomes more pronounced., B. The moon illusion remains the same., C. The moon illusion disappears entirely., D. The moon illusion is reversed. Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Have you ever noticed how the full moon looks bigger when it's near the horizon than when it's high over head? If so, you're not alone. People have wondered about this strange effect since ancient times, and surprisingly, we still don't have a great explanation, but that's not for lack of trying. Some of the greatest minds in history - Aristotle, Ptolemy, Da Vinci, Decartes - have all wrestled with this problem and failed to generate an adequate explanation. One of the first ideas suggested was that the image of the moon in the sky really is bigger near the horizon. Perhaps the Earth's atmosphere acts like a giant lens, magnifying the moon as it rises and sets. But this explanation doesn't cut it. If anything, the refraction of the atmosphere would make the moon look slightly smaller. Plus, if you actually measure the size of the visible moon at different positions, it doesn't change at all. But then, why does it still seem bigger when it's rising? This must be some kind of optical illusion. The question is, which one? One explanation is the Ebbinghaus Illusion, where two identical objects look different because of the relative size of the objects they're surrounded by. Here the two center circles are actually the same size. Maybe the moon looks bigger near the horizon because it's next to tiny trees, houses, and towers in the distance. But when the moon is higher up, it's surrounded by the vast darkness of the night sky and looks tiny by comparison. Another possibility is the famous Ponzo Illusion. If you've ever tried to draw in perspective, you know that the closer something is to the horizon, the smaller you should draw it. Our brain compensates automatically for this by perceiving objects near the horizon as larger than they actually appear. The two yellow lines in this drawing are the same size, but the upper one seems bigger because we interpret it as receding farther into the horizon. So, between Ponzo and Ebbinghaus, it seems like we've solved the mystery of the moon illusion, but, unfortunately, there are a few details that complicate things. For one thing, if this was just the Ebbinghaus effect, then we would expect the moon illusion to disappear for pilots flying high above the clouds since there wouldn't be any other smaller objects near the horizon. But in fact, pilots and sailors out on the ocean still claim to see the moon illusion. On the other hand, if it's just our brain's autocorrecting the size of objects near the horizon, then we'd expect the moon illusion to be visible inside a planetarium, where the whole sky, including the horizon, is displayed on a spherical dome overhead. Studies have shown, though, that this is not the case. To make matters worse, it seems the moon illusion disappears entirely if you just bend over and look at the moon between your legs. Now, this is just getting ridiculous! One of the most promising explanations today is known as Convergence Micropsia. Our brains judge the distance to objects and their apparent size by the focus of our eyes. When looking at the horizon, your eyes focus far off into the distance so your brain knows you're looking far away. The moon appears a certain size. Your brain thinks it's far away, which it is, so you naturally conclude the moon must be big. But when looking up at the night sky, there's nothing for your eyes to focus on, so they default to their rest focus, which is a point just a few meters away. Now your brain thinks the moon is much closer than it really is, so you naturally conclude the moon's not as big as you thought it was. Rather than explain why the moon looks so big near the horizon, Convergence Microspia explains why the moon looks so small when overhead. Still not satisfied? Well, frankly, neither are many scientists, so the debate over the moon illusion still rages on and may continue as long as we still see it in the night sky.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is the name given to the most promising explanation of the moon illusion?
Options: A. Refraction, B. Ebbinghaus illusion, C. Ponzo illusion, D. Convergence micropsia
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Have you experienced déjà vu? It's that shadowy feeling you get
when a situation seems familiar. A scene in a restaurant plays out
exactly as you remember. The world moves like a ballet
you've choreographed, but the sequence can't be based
on a past experience because you've never eaten here before. This is the first time you've had clams, so what's going on? Unfortunately, there isn't
one single explanation for déjà vu. The experience is brief
and occurs without notice, making it nearly impossible
for scientists to record and study it. Scientists can't simply sit around
and wait for it to happen to them -- this could take years. It has no physical manifestations and in studies, it's described by the subject
as a sensation or feeling. Because of this lack of hard evidence, there's been a surplus
of speculation over the years. Since Emile Boirac introduced déjà vu as a French term meaning "already seen," more than 40 theories attempt
to explain this phenomenon. Still, recent advancements in neuroimaging
and cognitive psychology narrow down the field of prospects. Let's walk through three of today's
more prevalent theories, using the same
restaurant setting for each. First up is dual processing. We'll need an action. Let's go with a waiter
dropping a tray of dishes. As the scene unfolds, your brain's hemispheres process
a flurry of information: the waiter's flailing arms, his cry for help, the smell of pasta. Within milliseconds, this information
zips through pathways and is processed into a single moment. Most of the time,
everything is recorded in-sync. However, this theory asserts that déjà vu occurs
when there's a slight delay in information from one of these pathways. The difference in arrival times causes the brain to interpret
the late information as a separate event. When it plays
over the already-recorded moment, it feels as if it's happened before because, in a sense, it has. Our next theory deals
with a confusion of the past rather than a mistake in the present. This is the hologram theory, and we'll use that tablecloth
to examine it. As you scan its squares, a distant memory swims up
from deep within your brain. According to the theory, this is because memories are stored in the form of holograms, and in holograms, you only need one fragment
to see the whole picture. Your brain has identified the tablecloth
with one from the past, maybe from your grandmother's house. However, instead of remembering
that you've seen it at your grandmother's, your brain has summoned up the old memory without identifying it. This leaves you stuck with familiarity,
but no recollection. Although you've never been
in this restaurant, you've seen that tablecloth
but are just failing to identify it. Now, look at this fork. Are you paying attention? Our last theory is divided attention, and it states that déjà vu occurs when our brain subliminally
takes in an environment while we're distracted
by one particular object. When our attention returns, we feel as if we've been here before. For example, just now
you focused on the fork and didn't observe the tablecloth
or the falling waiter. Although your brain has been
recording everything in your peripheral vision, it's been doing so
below conscious awareness. When you finally pull yourself
away from the fork, you think you've been here before
because you have, you just weren't paying attention. While all three of these theories
share the common features of déjà vu, none of them propose to be
the conclusive source of the phenomenon. Still, while we wait
for researchers and inventers to come up with new ways
to capture this fleeting moment, we can study the moment ourselves. After all, most studies of déjà vu
are based on first-hand accounts, so why can't one be yours? The next time you get déjà vu,
take a moment to think about it. Have you been distracted? Is there a familiar object somewhere? Is your brain just acting slow? Or is it something else?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What are the physical manifestations of déjà vu?
Options: A. Dizziness, B. Ringing in the ears, C. Sneezing, D. None
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the term "déjà vu" literally translated to in English? Options: A. Already experienced, B. Already seen, C. Familiar sensation, D. Past memory Correct Option: B
Question 2: Why is it challenging for scientists to study déjà vu? Options: A. It has no physical manifestations and occurs without notice., B. It is a rare phenomenon that only occurs in certain individuals., C. It is a complex phenomenon that requires advanced technology to study., D. It is a subjective experience that cannot be objectively measured. Correct Option: A
Question 3: According to the dual processing theory, what causes déjà vu to occur? Options: A. A slight delay in information from one of the brain's pathways., B. A confusion of past and present memories., C. A failure to identify a familiar object., D. A distraction from one's surroundings. Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the main idea behind the hologram theory of déjà vu? Options: A. Memories are stored in the form of holograms, and a fragment of a memory can trigger a feeling of familiarity., B. Déjà vu occurs when the brain subliminally takes in an environment while distracted by one particular object., C. Déjà vu is caused by a slight delay in information from one of the brain's pathways., D. Déjà vu is a result of a confusion of past and present memories. Correct Option: A
Question 5: A person is at a restaurant and feels like they've been there before, even though they know they haven't. What might be happening according to the divided attention theory? Options: A. Their brain is processing information from a past experience and confusing it with the present., B. Their brain is subliminally taking in the environment while they're distracted by one particular object., C. Their brain is experiencing a slight delay in information from one of its pathways., D. Their brain is failing to identify a familiar object. Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is a common feature among the three theories of déjà vu discussed in the transcript? Options: A. They all propose that déjà vu is a result of a neurological disorder., B. They all suggest that déjà vu is a rare phenomenon., C. They all attempt to explain the feeling of familiarity that occurs during déjà vu., D. They all propose that déjà vu is a result of a past traumatic experience. Correct Option: C
Question 7: Why might a person's brain summon up an old memory without identifying it, according to the hologram theory? Options: A. Because the memory is stored in a way that makes it difficult to retrieve., B. Because the person is distracted by their surroundings., C. Because the brain only needs one fragment of the memory to recall the whole picture., D. Because the person is experiencing a neurological disorder. Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is one way that researchers can study déjà vu, given its fleeting nature? Options: A. By conducting experiments in a controlled laboratory setting., B. By analyzing first-hand accounts of déjà vu experiences., C. By using advanced neuroimaging technology., D. By inducing déjà vu in participants. Correct Option: B
Question 9: According to the transcript, how many theories have been proposed to explain the phenomenon of déjà vu? Options: A. Over 10, B. Over 20, C. Over 40, D. Over 50 Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the author's suggestion for what to do the next time you experience déjà vu? Options: A. Try to ignore it and move on., B. Take a moment to think about it and try to understand what might be causing it., C. Attempt to recreate the experience., D. Seek medical attention. Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

The ground truth MCQ asks about the physical manifestations of déjà vu, and the correct answer is "None." Question 2 asks why it is challenging for scientists to study déjà vu, and the correct answer is "It has no physical manifestations and occurs without notice." 

While the questions are not identical, they both relate to the physical manifestations of déjà vu, or the lack thereof. The correct answers to both questions convey the same information: déjà vu does not have physical manifestations. 

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is 2.

everything is recorded in-sync. However, this theory asserts that déjà vu occurs
when there's a slight delay in information from one of these pathways. The difference in arrival times causes the brain to interpret
the late information as a separate event. When it plays
over the already-recorded moment, it feels as if it's happened before because, in a sense, it has. Our next theory deals
with a confusion of the past rather than a mistake in the present. This is the hologram theory, and we'll use that tablecloth
to examine it. As you scan its squares, a distant memory swims up
from deep within your brain. According to the theory, this is because memories are stored in the form of holograms, and in holograms, you only need one fragment
to see the whole picture. Your brain has identified the tablecloth
with one from the past, maybe from your grandmother's house. However, instead of remembering
that you've seen it at your grandmother's, your brain has summoned up the old memory without identifying it. This leaves you stuck with familiarity,
but no recollection. Although you've never been
in this restaurant, you've seen that tablecloth
but are just failing to identify it. Now, look at this fork. Are you paying attention? Our last theory is divided attention, and it states that déjà vu occurs when our brain subliminally
takes in an environment while we're distracted
by one particular object. When our attention returns, we feel as if we've been here before. For example, just now
you focused on the fork and didn't observe the tablecloth
or the falling waiter. Although your brain has been
recording everything in your peripheral vision, it's been doing so
below conscious awareness. When you finally pull yourself
away from the fork, you think you've been here before
because you have, you just weren't paying attention. While all three of these theories
share the common features of déjà vu, none of them propose to be
the conclusive source of the phenomenon. Still, while we wait
for researchers and inventers to come up with new ways
to capture this fleeting moment, we can study the moment ourselves. After all, most studies of déjà vu
are based on first-hand accounts, so why can't one be yours? The next time you get déjà vu,
take a moment to think about it. Have you been distracted? Is there a familiar object somewhere? Is your brain just acting slow? Or is it something else?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How many theories of déjà vu are there?
Options: A. 10, B. 3, C. Over 40, D. None
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the term "déjà vu" literally translated to in English? Options: A. Already experienced, B. Already seen, C. Familiar sensation, D. Past memory Correct Option: B
Question 2: Why is it challenging for scientists to study déjà vu? Options: A. It has no physical manifestations and occurs without notice., B. It is a rare phenomenon that only occurs in certain individuals., C. It is a complex phenomenon that requires advanced technology to study., D. It is a subjective experience that cannot be objectively measured. Correct Option: A
Question 3: According to the dual processing theory, what causes déjà vu to occur? Options: A. A slight delay in information from one of the brain's pathways., B. A confusion of past and present memories., C. A failure to identify a familiar object., D. A distraction from one's surroundings. Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the main idea behind the hologram theory of déjà vu? Options: A. Memories are stored in the form of holograms, and a fragment of a memory can trigger a feeling of familiarity., B. Déjà vu occurs when the brain subliminally takes in an environment while distracted by one particular object., C. Déjà vu is caused by a slight delay in information from one of the brain's pathways., D. Déjà vu is a result of a confusion of past and present memories. Correct Option: A
Question 5: A person is at a restaurant and feels like they've been there before, even though they know they haven't. What might be happening according to the divided attention theory? Options: A. Their brain is processing information from a past experience and confusing it with the present., B. Their brain is subliminally taking in the environment while they're distracted by one particular object., C. Their brain is experiencing a slight delay in information from one of its pathways., D. Their brain is failing to identify a familiar object. Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is a common feature among the three theories of déjà vu discussed in the transcript? Options: A. They all propose that déjà vu is a result of a neurological disorder., B. They all suggest that déjà vu is a rare phenomenon., C. They all attempt to explain the feeling of familiarity that occurs during déjà vu., D. They all propose that déjà vu is a result of a past traumatic experience. Correct Option: C
Question 7: Why might a person's brain summon up an old memory without identifying it, according to the hologram theory? Options: A. Because the memory is stored in a way that makes it difficult to retrieve., B. Because the person is distracted by their surroundings., C. Because the brain only needs one fragment of the memory to recall the whole picture., D. Because the person is experiencing a neurological disorder. Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is one way that researchers can study déjà vu, given its fleeting nature? Options: A. By conducting experiments in a controlled laboratory setting., B. By analyzing first-hand accounts of déjà vu experiences., C. By using advanced neuroimaging technology., D. By inducing déjà vu in participants. Correct Option: B

Take a moment to think about it and try to understand what might be causing it., C. Attempt to recreate the experience., D. Seek medical attention. Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Have you experienced déjà vu? It's that shadowy feeling you get
when a situation seems familiar. A scene in a restaurant plays out
exactly as you remember. The world moves like a ballet
you've choreographed, but the sequence can't be based
on a past experience because you've never eaten here before. This is the first time you've had clams, so what's going on? Unfortunately, there isn't
one single explanation for déjà vu. The experience is brief
and occurs without notice, making it nearly impossible
for scientists to record and study it. Scientists can't simply sit around
and wait for it to happen to them -- this could take years. It has no physical manifestations and in studies, it's described by the subject
as a sensation or feeling. Because of this lack of hard evidence, there's been a surplus
of speculation over the years. Since Emile Boirac introduced déjà vu as a French term meaning "already seen," more than 40 theories attempt
to explain this phenomenon. Still, recent advancements in neuroimaging
and cognitive psychology narrow down the field of prospects. Let's walk through three of today's
more prevalent theories, using the same
restaurant setting for each. First up is dual processing. We'll need an action. Let's go with a waiter
dropping a tray of dishes. As the scene unfolds, your brain's hemispheres process
a flurry of information: the waiter's flailing arms, his cry for help, the smell of pasta. Within milliseconds, this information
zips through pathways and is processed into a single moment. Most of the time,
everything is recorded in-sync. However, this theory asserts that déjà vu occurs
when there's a slight delay in information from one of these pathways. The difference in arrival times causes the brain to interpret
the late information as a separate event. When it plays
over the already-recorded moment, it feels as if it's happened before because, in a sense, it has. Our next theory deals
with a confusion of the past rather than a mistake in the present. This is the hologram theory, and we'll use that tablecloth
to examine it. As you scan its squares, a distant memory swims up
from deep within your brain. According to the theory, this is because memories are stored in the form of holograms, and in holograms, you only need one fragment
to see the whole picture. Your brain has identified the tablecloth
with one from the past, maybe from your grandmother's house. However, instead of remembering
that you've seen it at your grandmother's, your brain has summoned up the old memory without identifying it. This leaves you stuck with familiarity,
but no recollection. Although you've never been
in this restaurant, you've seen that tablecloth
but are just failing to identify it. Now, look at this fork. Are you paying attention? Our last theory is divided attention, and it states that déjà vu occurs when our brain subliminally
takes in an environment while we're distracted
by one particular object. When our attention returns, we feel as if we've been here before. For example, just now
you focused on the fork and didn't observe the tablecloth
or the falling waiter. Although your brain has been
recording everything in your peripheral vision, it's been doing so
below conscious awareness. When you finally pull yourself
away from the fork, you think you've been here before
because you have, you just weren't paying attention. While all three of these theories
share the common features of déjà vu, none of them propose to be
the conclusive source of the phenomenon. Still, while we wait
for researchers and inventers to come up with new ways
to capture this fleeting moment, we can study the moment ourselves. After all, most studies of déjà vu
are based on first-hand accounts, so why can't one be yours? The next time you get déjà vu,
take a moment to think about it. Have you been distracted? Is there a familiar object somewhere? Is your brain just acting slow? Or is it something else?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which theory asserts that déjà vu occurs when there is a delay in information to your brian?
Options: A. Double imaging, B. Delayed Response, C. Hologram Theory, D. Dual Processing
Correct Option: D

exactly as you remember. The world moves like a ballet
you've choreographed, but the sequence can't be based

as a sensation or feeling. Because of this lack of hard evidence, there's been a surplus
of speculation over the years. Since Emile Boirac introduced déjà vu as a French term meaning "already seen," more than 40 theories attempt
to explain this phenomenon. Still, recent advancements in neuroimaging
and cognitive psychology narrow down the field of prospects. Let's walk through three of today's
more prevalent theories, using the same

to see the whole picture. Your brain has identified the tablecloth
with one from the past, maybe from your grandmother's house. However, instead of remembering

in this restaurant, you've seen that tablecloth

takes in an environment while we're distracted

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Using the word Shakespeare within any classroom in the 21st century has become almost as dangerous for teachers as putting balloons in a toaster. After uttering this simple word, the common teacher is met with a mass of groans, moans, devastated looks, and the occasional chair tossed in his or her direction. But Shakespearean works are not boring, confusing, long and painful plays written more than 400 years ago. They're adventures relating to the extremities of human nature: love, hate, jealousy, zealous ambition, fear, mistrust, deception, and murder. We owe much of our own language to his invention. He invented over 2,000 words for use in his plays, which still remain in the Oxford English Dictionary. Words like "countless" and "assassination" as well as phrases like "one fell swoop," "foul play," and even "to be in a pickle" all originated from William's brilliant brain. And there are many echoes of Shakespeare's romantic language too. If you read Romeo and Juliet, you'll come across sentences like, "She doth teach the torches to burn bright," and, "So shows a snowy dove trooping with crows." Both are quite clever metaphors, suggesting that Juliet is both exceptionally beautiful and far moreso than anyone else. "For thou art as glorious to this night, being o'er my head, as is a winged messenger of heaven," is a simile suggesting angelic qualities of the lady in question. This is not too different from today's comments like, "Hey, beautiful!" and, "You're the hottest girl in the room." Shakespeare also uses slightly more complex metaphors to describe the intentions of a mischievous man. For instance, "This holy shrine, the gentle sin is this: My lips, two blushing pilgrims, ready stand to smooth that rough touch with a tender kiss," essentially means, "I wish to kiss you." Such male intentions were not limited to simple pecks on the cheek either. An intentional ambiguity was often used as a cheeky means to proposition marriage or a more intimate relationship. Therefore, instead of viewing Shakespearean works as out-dated, boring, and unhelpful, start reading today and discover the best ways to get the one you love to love you back.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Shakespeare’s plays were written in the ________.
Options: A. 1500's and 1600's, B. 1100's and 1200's, C. 2000 BC, D. 1960's
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the typical reaction of students when a teacher mentions the word "Shakespeare" in a 21st-century classroom? Options: A. Enthusiasm and eagerness to learn, B. Groans, moans, and devastated looks, C. Indifference and lack of interest, D. Curiosity and questions about his life Correct Option: B
Question 2: What are Shakespearean works primarily about? Options: A. Historical events and cultural norms of the 16th century, B. Scientific discoveries and philosophical theories of the time, C. Adventures relating to the extremities of human nature, D. Mythological creatures and legendary tales from ancient civilizations Correct Option: C
Question 3: According to the Oxford English Dictionary, how many words did Shakespeare invent for use in his plays? Options: A. Over 1,000 words, B. Over 2,000 words, C. Over 3,000 words, D. Over 5,000 words Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the phrase "to be in a pickle" an example of? Options: A. A metaphor from Romeo and Juliet, B. A phrase coined by Shakespeare that is still in use today, C. A modern idiomatic expression with no connection to Shakespeare's works, D. A simile from Hamlet Correct Option: B
Question 5: What literary device is used in the sentence "She doth teach the torches to burn bright"? Options: A. Simile, B. Metaphor, C. Alliteration, D. Personification Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the speaker's intention in the passage "This holy shrine, the gentle sin is this: My lips, two blushing pilgrims, ready stand to smooth that rough touch with a tender kiss"? Options: A. To express platonic affection and appreciation, B. To proposition a romantic relationship, C. To ask for forgiveness and pardon, D. To declare admiration from afar without expectation of reciprocation Correct Option: B
Question 7: How does the speaker suggest that reading Shakespeare can be helpful? Options: A. It can improve your knowledge of historical events and cultural norms, B. It can help you understand scientific theories and philosophical concepts, C. It can provide insight into human nature and relationships, D. It can improve your writing skills and literary analysis Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the tone of the passage when discussing Shakespeare's works? Options: A. Critical and dismissive of their value, B. Neutral and objective in their assessment, C. Enthusiastic and encouraging of their study, D. Sarcastic and humorous in their critique Correct Option: C
Question 9: How does the speaker compare Shakespeare's romantic language to modern-day expressions? Options: A. Shakespeare's language is more complex and poetic than modern expressions, B. Modern-day expressions are more romantic and sincere than Shakespeare's language, C. Shakespeare's language is similar to modern-day expressions in its intention and sentiment, D. Shakespeare's language is outdated and irrelevant in modern times Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the overall message of the passage regarding Shakespeare's works? Options: A. They are boring, irrelevant, and lack value in modern times, B. They are only for scholars and academics to study and appreciate, C. They are timeless, providing valuable insights into human nature and relationships, D. They are only for entertainment purposes, lacking any deeper meaning Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that the most similar generated MCQ is not an exact match, but Question 3 is the closest in terms of question intent and content.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the time period when Shakespeare's plays were written, while Question 3 asks about the number of words Shakespeare invented for use in his plays. However, Question 3 is the only generated MCQ that provides a specific historical fact about Shakespeare's works, which is related to the time period when he wrote his plays.

Although there is no direct match, I would recommend Question 3 as the most similar generated MCQ, with the understanding that it does not perfectly match the ground truth MCQ.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 3

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Using the word Shakespeare within any classroom in the 21st century has become almost as dangerous for teachers as putting balloons in a toaster. After uttering this simple word, the common teacher is met with a mass of groans, moans, devastated looks, and the occasional chair tossed in his or her direction. They're adventures relating to the extremities of human nature: love, hate, jealousy, zealous ambition, fear, mistrust, deception, and murder. We owe much of our own language to his invention. He invented over 2,000 words for use in his plays, which still remain in the Oxford English Dictionary. And there are many echoes of Shakespeare's romantic language too. For instance, "This holy shrine, the gentle sin is this: My lips, two blushing pilgrims, ready stand to smooth that rough touch with a tender kiss," essentially means, "I wish to kiss you." **Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What are the common student responses to Shakespearean plays in the 21st Century?
Options: A. crying, screaming and shouting, B. groans, moans, devastated looks and chair throwing, C. smiles, laughter and excitement, D. ‘a’ and ‘b’
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the typical reaction of students when a teacher mentions the word "Shakespeare" in a 21st-century classroom? Options: A. Enthusiasm and eagerness to learn, B. Groans, moans, and devastated looks, C. Indifference and lack of interest, D. Curiosity and questions about his life Correct Option: B
Question 2: What are Shakespearean works primarily about? Options: A. Historical events and cultural norms of the 16th century, B. Scientific discoveries and philosophical theories of the time, C. Adventures relating to the extremities of human nature, D. Mythological creatures and legendary tales from ancient civilizations Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Using the word Shakespeare within any classroom in the 21st century has become almost as dangerous for teachers as putting balloons in a toaster. After uttering this simple word, the common teacher is met with a mass of groans, moans, devastated looks, and the occasional chair tossed in his or her direction. But Shakespearean works are not boring, confusing, long and painful plays written more than 400 years ago. They're adventures relating to the extremities of human nature: love, hate, jealousy, zealous ambition, fear, mistrust, deception, and murder. We owe much of our own language to his invention. He invented over 2,000 words for use in his plays, which still remain in the Oxford English Dictionary. Words like "countless" and "assassination" as well as phrases like "one fell swoop," "foul play," and even "to be in a pickle" all originated from William's brilliant brain. And there are many echoes of Shakespeare's romantic language too. If you read Romeo and Juliet, you'll come across sentences like, "She doth teach the torches to burn bright," and, "So shows a snowy dove trooping with crows." Both are quite clever metaphors, suggesting that Juliet is both exceptionally beautiful and far moreso than anyone else. "For thou art as glorious to this night, being o'er my head, as is a winged messenger of heaven," is a simile suggesting angelic qualities of the lady in question. This is not too different from today's comments like, "Hey, beautiful!" and, "You're the hottest girl in the room." Shakespeare also uses slightly more complex metaphors to describe the intentions of a mischievous man. For instance, "This holy shrine, the gentle sin is this: My lips, two blushing pilgrims, ready stand to smooth that rough touch with a tender kiss," essentially means, "I wish to kiss you." Such male intentions were not limited to simple pecks on the cheek either. An intentional ambiguity was often used as a cheeky means to proposition marriage or a more intimate relationship. Therefore, instead of viewing Shakespearean works as out-dated, boring, and unhelpful, start reading today and discover the best ways to get the one you love to love you back.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which phrase did Shakespeare not invent?
Options: A. foul play, B. to be in a pickle, C. you are as beautiful as this hour, D. she doth teach the torches to burn bright
Correct Option: C

**Transcript**:
Using the word Shakespeare within any classroom in the 21st century has become almost as dangerous for teachers as putting balloons in a toaster. After uttering this simple word, the common teacher is met with a mass of groans, moans, devastated looks, and the occasional chair tossed in his or her direction. But Shakespearean works are not boring, confusing, long and painful plays written more than 400 years ago. They're adventures relating to the extremities of human nature: love, hate, jealousy, zealous ambition, fear, mistrust, deception, and murder. We owe much of our own language to his invention. He invented over 2,000 words for use in his plays, which still remain in the Oxford English Dictionary. Words like "countless" and "assassination" as well as phrases like "one fell swoop," "foul play," and even "to be in a pickle" all originated from William's brilliant brain. And there are many echoes of Shakespeare's romantic language too. If you read Romeo and Juliet, you'll come across sentences like, "She doth teach the torches to burn bright," and, "So shows a snowy dove trooping with crows." Both are quite clever metaphors, suggesting that Juliet is both exceptionally beautiful and far moreso than anyone else. "For thou art as glorious to this night, being o'er my head, as is a winged messenger of heaven," is a simile suggesting angelic qualities of the lady in question. This is not too different from today's comments like, "Hey, beautiful!" and, "You're the hottest girl in the room." Shakespeare also uses slightly more complex metaphors to describe the intentions of a mischievous man. For instance, "This holy shrine, the gentle sin is this: My lips, two blushing pilgrims, ready stand to smooth that rough touch with a tender kiss," essentially means, "I wish to kiss you." Such male intentions were not limited to simple pecks on the cheek either. An intentional ambiguity was often used as a cheeky means to proposition marriage or a more intimate relationship. Therefore, instead of viewing Shakespearean works as out-dated, boring, and unhelpful, start reading today and discover the best ways to get the one you love to love you back.

Correct Option: A

**Transcript**:
Using the word Shakespeare within any classroom in the 21st century has become almost as dangerous for teachers as putting balloons in a toaster. After uttering this simple word, the common teacher is met with a mass of groans, moans, devastated looks, and the occasional chair tossed in his or her direction. Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
As you can see, I was born without fingers on my right hand. And also my right leg was several inches shorter than my left one. They broke the bones in the leg, then they screwed metal spikes into the bone. It has not only spikes, but wires that go all the way through the leg to stabilize it. I have to walk on it. I have to stretch it out so that my muscles don't just get all atrophied. People always ask me, "Does it hurt?" Yes, it does, but I focus on what I can do, not on what I cannot do. I want to talk with you guys about overcoming obstacles. Everybody has obstacles, a disability, a hurdle. We face a choice: Let the obstacle overcome you or overcome the obstacle. Maybe some of you have heard of Jim Abbott. He was a Major League baseball player. He won a gold metal in the Olympics. He played for the Yankees, the Angels. But he threw a no-hitter, and he only had one arm. When he was a kid, he came home mad one time and told his dad, "The kids won't let me play baseball because I only have one hand." His dad replied, "No, the kids won't let you play baseball because you stink at baseball. You can't change the fact that you only have one hand, but you can change the fact that you stink." So, his dad began to practice with him, and he got good. He overcame obstacles. Teams would try to exploit his weak side. They would try to bunt to the side that he had a missing arm. But they never succeeded because he practiced and practiced fielding bunts to that side. There's no dishonor in having a disability, and I won't let anyone diss my ability, but I don't want anyone's pity either. I will not use the obstacles I face as an excuse for having a pity party. I will practice harder, play harder, and push myself harder to keep getting better. Last season I started on my varsity high school basketball team as a freshman, and I won Rookie of the Year. I was one of the top scorers on the team. One of the things that I find funny is that people judge me by appearance. They say, "Oh, look at this one-handed whitey with the limp. I don't want him on my team!" But what they don't know is that I don't just have a disability, I have an ability. One of my favorite moments from this last season was we played a team that we had never played before. And when the game started, you could tell that they were dissing my disability. I mean, they double-teamed our tallest player. They just were playing really soft on me, and they just, you could tell they thought, "What can this guy with one hand do?" So, they left me open for a three. I made that one. They left me open for another one. I made that one. Then, they started to get frustrated, so they actually fouled me. I made both free throws. And they called time out. And as we were in the huddle, I could hear the other coach yelling at his players about me. They went from not covering me at all to double-teaming me. It's all about overcoming obstacles. It's true, I have a disability, but so do you. I also have an ability, so do you. Everyone has obstacles to overcome. Some are visible like mine. Some are less visible. Maybe your obstacle is that you come from a poor neighborhood. Maybe people say you'll never amount to anything. Prove them wrong. Maybe your obstacle is that you have a learning disability, and people think that you're dumb. Prove them wrong. Maybe people judge you because of the color of your skin or your family background. Prove them wrong. I know a lot of people who take one look at me and judge me. They say, "Oh, that kid can't be any good at basketball. One leg, one hand." If someone things you can't overcome the obstacles, prove them wrong.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which activity helped Steven overcome his obstacles?
Options: A. Playing football, B. Singing, C. Playing basketball, D. Swimming
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
As you can see, I was born without fingers on my right hand. And also my right leg was several inches shorter than my left one. They broke the bones in the leg, then they screwed metal spikes into the bone. It has not only spikes, but wires that go all the way through the leg to stabilize it. I have to walk on it. I have to stretch it out so that my muscles don't just get all atrophied. People always ask me, "Does it hurt?" Yes, it does, but I focus on what I can do, not on what I cannot do. I want to talk with you guys about overcoming obstacles. Everybody has obstacles, a disability, a hurdle. We face a choice: Let the obstacle overcome you or overcome the obstacle. Maybe some of you have heard of Jim Abbott. He was a Major League baseball player. He won a gold metal in the Olympics. He played for the Yankees, the Angels. But he threw a no-hitter, and he only had one arm. When he was a kid, he came home mad one time and told his dad, "The kids won't let me play baseball because I only have one hand." His dad replied, "No, the kids won't let you play baseball because you stink at baseball. You can't change the fact that you only have one hand, but you can change the fact that you stink." So, his dad began to practice with him, and he got good. He overcame obstacles. Teams would try to exploit his weak side. They would try to bunt to the side that he had a missing arm. But they never succeeded because he practiced and practiced fielding bunts to that side. There's no dishonor in having a disability, and I won't let anyone diss my ability, but I don't want anyone's pity either. I will not use the obstacles I face as an excuse for having a pity party. I will practice harder, play harder, and push myself harder to keep getting better. Last season I started on my varsity high school basketball team as a freshman, and I won Rookie of the Year. I was one of the top scorers on the team. One of the things that I find funny is that people judge me by appearance. They say, "Oh, look at this one-handed whitey with the limp. I don't want him on my team!" But what they don't know is that I don't just have a disability, I have an ability. One of my favorite moments from this last season was we played a team that we had never played before. And when the game started, you could tell that they were dissing my disability. I mean, they double-teamed our tallest player. They just were playing really soft on me, and they just, you could tell they thought, "What can this guy with one hand do?" So, they left me open for a three. I made that one. They left me open for another one. I made that one. Then, they started to get frustrated, so they actually fouled me. I made both free throws. And they called time out. And as we were in the huddle, I could hear the other coach yelling at his players about me. They went from not covering me at all to double-teaming me. It's all about overcoming obstacles. It's true, I have a disability, but so do you. I also have an ability, so do you. Everyone has obstacles to overcome. Some are visible like mine. Some are less visible. Maybe your obstacle is that you come from a poor neighborhood. Maybe people say you'll never amount to anything. Prove them wrong. Maybe your obstacle is that you have a learning disability, and people think that you're dumb. Prove them wrong. Maybe people judge you because of the color of your skin or your family background. Prove them wrong. I know a lot of people who take one look at me and judge me. They say, "Oh, that kid can't be any good at basketball. One leg, one hand." If someone things you can't overcome the obstacles, prove them wrong.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why did Steven require surgery?
Options: A. He suffered a concussion, B. His right leg was shorter than his left leg, C. He had appendicitis, D. He broke his ankle playing football
Correct Option: B
